content.title: Angiosome Concept in Limb Salvage
content.description: The anatomic basis for targeting revascularization to the specific arterial territory supplying a wound, optimizing healing in critical limb ischemia.
content.definition: Angiosomes are three-dimensional blocks of tissue supplied by specific source arteries. In the foot, six angiosomes are defined: three from posterior tibial artery (medial calcaneal, medial plantar, lateral plantar), two from anterior tibial artery (anterior ankle, dorsal foot), and one from peroneal artery (lateral calcaneal). Direct revascularization targets the artery feeding the wound's angiosome.

foot_angiosomes: Posterior tibial - Medial calcaneal: Heel (medial and plantar)
Posterior tibial - Medial plantar: Medial midfoot and great toe
Posterior tibial - Lateral plantar: Lateral forefoot and lesser toes
Anterior tibial/DP - Anterior ankle: Anterior ankle
Anterior tibial/DP - Dorsal foot: Foot dorsum
Peroneal - Lateral calcaneal: Lateral ankle and heel
clinical_application: Direct revascularization: Treat artery feeding wound angiosome
Indirect revascularization: Treat adjacent angiosome via collaterals
Direct revascularization associated with better healing
Indirect may be acceptable if direct not technically feasible
supporting_evidence: Multiple studies show improved wound healing with direct revasc
Benefit most pronounced in diabetics with poor collaterals
Peroneal-only revascularization may have worse outcomes for forefoot wounds
Concept guides but does not mandate treatment decisions

learning_objectives: Define angiosome territories of the foot
Apply angiosome concept to treatment planning
clinical_pearls: Diabetics have impaired collateral formation - direct revasc more important
Heel wounds typically require PT or peroneal revascularization
Forefoot wounds best served by AT/DP or PT lateral plantar
If only one vessel can be treated, prioritize angiosome feeding wound
Straight-line flow to foot may matter more than angiosome specificity
